p: We assumed that infectivity was indicated by a positive test result and that, based on individual test results ( Table 3), the infectious period was preceded by a latent period. This latent period began immediately after virus inoculation (day 0) and ended at a time point (T 1) between the last negative and the first positive test result. Consequently, the infectious period started just after the latent period and ended in the period (T 2) between the last positive test and the subsequent negative test. For example, bird k2 in Table 3 (dataset A) showed a latent period starting at day 0 and lasting to somewhere between day 3 and 5 (3<T 1<5); the infectious period lasted from T 1 to between day 10 and 12 (10< T 2<12). We then assumed that both the latent period ( LP) and infectious period ( IP) in the population of infected birds followed a gamma distribution, characterized by parameters κ and ρ, as follows:
